TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants , PERSON and Mr PERSON , are NORP nationals , who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The applicants , a married couple , built a house in GPE in DATE . The house is located on an estate of detached family houses .

CARDINAL . In DATE the GPE municipality sold a plot of land to HIT PERSON Polska Piastów CARDINAL sp . z. o.o . ( “ the HIT company ” ) . According to the applicants , the sales contract was conditional on the issuance of the planning permission for the construction of a commercial centre .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the Mayor of GPE granted planning permission ( decyzja o warunkach zabudowy i zagospodarowania terenu ) to the HIT company for the construction of a commercial centre . The Mayor found that the planned commercial centre conformed to the local development plan . The decision provided that on one side of the commercial centre the investor was required to erect a minimum QUANTITY high screen between the delivery area of the centre and the neighbouring houses .

CARDINAL . It appears that the applicants were not informed about the grant of the planning permission despite the fact that their house was directly adjacent to the area of the future development . As a result , they could not lodge a regular appeal against the grant of planning permission .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Mayor of GPE partly altered the planning permission by adding another plot to the planned development .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants requested ORG to declare the planning permission null and void . They argued that it had been issued contrary to the provisions of the local development plan . On DATE ORG refused the request and subsequently confirmed its decision on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed both decisions of ORG as being issued prematurely . Subsequently , ORG dismissed the cassation appeal lodged by the HIT company .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again refused to declare the planning permission null and void . On DATE ORG confirmed its earlier decision . The applicants together with other neighbours and CARDINAL local associations appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed both decisions of ORG . It observed that pursuant to ORG a planning permission was null and void if it was contrary to the local development plan . The court found that the local development plan in GPE had reserved the relevant part of the town for green zones and services with accompanying green zones . It accordingly held that ORG had erred in its examination of the provisions of the local development plan related to the area on which the commercial centre was to be built . Furthermore , ORG had erred in its assessment of the adverse environmental impact of the commercial centre . The court referred in this respect to ORG judgment of DATE ( case no . PERSON CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL , see below ) . It noted , among other things , that the delivery area of the commercial centre on the Harcerska street side was to be isolated by a minimum QUANTITY high wall from the neighbouring estate of detached houses .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , following the findings of ORG , declared the planning permission null and void pursuant to LAW ) and ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . The primary reason for the annulment decision was that the planning permission had been issued in breach of the local development plan . On DATE ORG confirmed its decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the HIT company ’s complaint as being submitted out of time .

CARDINAL . Having obtained planning permission , the HIT company was required to obtain a construction permit . On DATE the Mayor of Piastów issued a construction permit ( pozwolenie na budowę ) for a commercial centre and supporting facilities . The applicants and other neighbours appealed . They submitted , inter alia , that the planned construction would be contrary to the local development plan . They also argued that the commercial centre would adversely affect their health and their homes .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Mayor of GPE issued an order ( postanowienie ) in which he altered a number of plots on which the commercial centre was to be constructed . That order was issued LAW which provided for rectification of clerical errors and obvious mistakes in administrative decisions . On DATE the ORG dismissed the applicants’ appeal against that order . The applicants appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Mazowiecki Governor dismissed the ORG appeal against the construction permit of DATE . Consequently , the construction permit became final and enforceable . It appears that shortly afterwards the HIT company started construction works .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against the Governor ’s decision to ORG . They argued , inter alia , that the adverse environmental impact of the commercial centre had not been duly addressed by the administrative authorities . The applicants also requested the administrative court to issue an interim order halting the enforcement of the construction permit . It appears that the court did not respond to this request .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( case no . ORG CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) quashed as unlawful the decision of the Governor and the construction permit issued by the Mayor . It found that the planned commercial centre was to be considered as having an adverse environmental impact within the meaning of the Ordinance of the Minister of ORG DATE . In this respect it had regard to the fact that the commercial centre would have a meat - processing capacity of QUANTITY per day , car park facilities for CARDINAL cars and a commercial surface area exceeding QUANTITY . The court noted that had the commercial centre been considered as a development adversely affecting the environment , the local authorities would have been required to follow stringent procedures . It further observed that :

“ As it transpires from the file , the authorities conducting the proceedings and the investor , were perfectly aware of the existing regulations and the relevant obligations ; however at all costs it was attempted to give the public an impression that the investment is not considered as having a potentially adverse impact on the environment , manipulating from the very beginning the number of plots , the number of places in the car park and interpreting narrowly the notion of “ a commercial centre ” .

The court observed that the authorities had failed to carry out relevant analyses of the environmental impact of the commercial centre and that their findings as to its environment - neutral status had been entirely unsubstantiated .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed as unlawful the Governor ’s order of DATE and the Mayor ’s order of CARDINAL DATE . It observed that the Mayor ’s order on rectification of the construction permit had been in fact a decision on the merits of the case and should have been issued in the form of an administrative decision . In addition , that rectification order had made the construction permit incompatible with the planning permission of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Mayor of GPE discontinued the proceedings concerning the issuance of the construction permit . It found that the construction of the commercial centre had been terminated in DATE and that the HIT company had begun operating it . In those circumstances , the proceedings concerning the construction permit had become devoid of purpose .
CARDINAL . The applicants appealed . On DATE the Mazowiecki Governor dismissed their appeal against the discontinuation of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicants lodged a complaint against that decision with ORG . On DATE the court dismissed their complaint . On DATE ORG dismissed the ORG cassation appeal against ORG judgment . The judgment was served on the applicants on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Mayor of GPE issued a permit for the use ( pozwolenie na użytkowanie obiektu budowlanego ) of the HIT commercial centre with the supporting facilities . It appears that the Mayor did not serve the decision on the applicants and other interested neighbours .

CARDINAL . The applicants together with a group of their neighbours and a local association “ Eko - Piastów ” appealed to the Mazowiecki Governor . On CARDINAL DATE the Governor found that the appeals had been submitted out of time . However , on DATE ORG quashed the Governor ’s decision .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , ORG of ORG became the competent authority to examine the appeal .

CARDINAL . The applicants requested that the permit for the use of the commercial centre be declared null and void . On DATE the ORG of ORG allowed that request . It found that the Mayor of GPE had issued the permit without having obtained the necessary authorisation from ORG . The latter authority had expressly informed the Mayor that due to the complexity of the case it would not be able to give its authorisation before DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Chief Inspector of ORG quashed the decision of ORG of CARDINAL DATE and discontinued the proceedings before the first - instance authority .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG quashed the Mayor ’s decision of DATE and remitted the case to ORG of ORG . ORG found that the Mayor of Piastów had not given sufficient reasons for his decision . CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides as follows :

“ In the exercise of his or her rights , an owner of immovable property shall refrain from actions which would infringe the enjoyment of adjacent immovable property and which go beyond the normal use arising from the socio - economic purpose of the immovable property and local relations . ”
Pursuant to LAW :

“ The owner shall have the right to claim restitution of his lawful position and acessation of infringements of the law , against a person who infringes his ownership otherwise than by depriving the owner of the actual control of the property in question . ”
There is no limitation period for claims under LAW if they relate to immovable property ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL et seq . of LAW ( ORG cywilny ) provide for the ORG ’s liability in tort . In the version applicable until DATE , Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL , which lays down a general rule , read as follows :
“ CARDINAL . ORG shall be liable for damage caused by a ORG official in the performance of the duties entrusted to him . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the Law of DATE on amendments to LAW and other statutes ( LOC o zmianie ustawy – ORG cywilny oraz niektórych innych ustaw ) ( “ the DATE Amendment ” ) entered into force . The relevant amendments were in essence aimed at enlarging the scope of ORG liability in tort under LAW of the Civil Code – including the addition of a new LAW .
The amended LAW reads as follows :

“ ORG , or [ as the case may be ] a local government entity or other legal person responsible for exercising public authority , shall be liable for any damage ( szkoda ) caused by an unlawful act or omission [ committed ] in connection with the exercise of public authority . ”
CARDINAL . Following LAW , Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL reads in so far as relevant :

“ Where damage has been caused by the delivery of a final ruling or a final decision , redress for such damage may be sought after their unlawfulness has been established in the relevant proceedings , except where provided otherwise by law . ”
However , under the transitional provisions of LAW , LAW as applicable before DATE applies to all events and legal situations that subsisted before that date .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the CAP ” ) ( ORG postępowania administracyjnego ) , which sets out grounds on which a final administrative decision is subject to annulment , states :
“ CARDINAL . A public administration authority shall declare a decision null and void if :
CARDINAL ) it has been issued in breach of the rules governing competence ;
CARDINAL ) NORP it has been issued without a legal basis or in flagrant breach of the law ;
CARDINAL ) concerns a case already decided by means of another final decision ;
CARDINAL ) it has been addressed to a person who is not a party to the case ;
CARDINAL ) it was unenforceable on the date of its issuance and its unenforceability is of a permanent nature ;
CARDINAL ) it would give rise to a punishable offence in the event that it has been enforced ;
CARDINAL ) it has a flaw making it null and void by the force of law .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the ORG set out principles for compensation for loss caused by the issuance of an administrative decision subsequently annulled on the grounds listed in LAW .

CARDINAL . This provision was repealed by LAW with effect from DATE and replaced by new LAW . However , under LAW , which sets out transitional rules , LAW , in the version applicable on the repeal date , still applies to “ events and legal situations ” that subsisted before the entry into force of LAW .
LAW , in the version applicable on the relevant date , read as follows :

“ CARDINAL . A party who has suffered a loss on account of the issuance of a decision in breach of LAW or on account of annulment of such a decision shall have a claim for compensation for actual damage , unless he has culpably caused the circumstances mentioned in this provision .
CARDINAL . NORP The provisions of LAW , except for LAW [ provision repealed ] , shall apply to [ such ] compensation .

CARDINAL . Compensation is due from an authority that issued a decision in breach of Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL , unless the other party to the proceedings concerning the decision culpably caused the circumstances mentioned in this provision ; in the latter case a claim for compensation shall be directed against the culpable party .

CARDINAL . A public administration authority that has declared a decision null and void or declared , pursuant to LAW , that it has been issued contrary to the law shall rule on compensation due from the authority referred to in LAW . A claim for compensation from a person who has culpably caused the circumstances mentioned in LAW , shall be pursued before a court of law .

CARDINAL . A party who is not satisfied with compensation granted by a public administration authority referred to in DATE , may lodge a claim with a court of law within DATE from the date of service of a decision given on that matter .

CARDINAL . A claim for compensation shall be time - barred after DATE from the date on which has become final the decision declaring null and void the decision issued in breach of LAW or decision whereby an authority has declared , pursuant to LAW , that the contested decision has been issued in breach of LAW . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG , sitting in plenary , gave a resolution ( no . III CZP CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) on the application of LAW and rules regarding compensation . The resolution was given in response to legal questions submitted by the First President of ORG in connection with certain problems and divergences arising in judicial practice , in particular in respect of the temporal effects of LAW as determined in LAW , the application of Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW which replaced LAW and rules for adjudicating compensation .

CARDINAL . The resolution contains an extensive reasoning which , in so far as relevant , may be summarised as follows : LAW § DATE and CARDINAL of the ORG applies to all claims for damages arising from an issuance of a final administrative decision given before DATE , which has been declared null and void or has been declared as being issued in breach of LAW CARDINAL of the ORG after that date . In contrast , paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL , setting out the procedure for vindicating such claims , should be considered as no longer applicable . Consequently , a party seeking compensation under this provision should file an action directly with a civil court .
